titleStmt.title: Old Age's Lambent Peaks
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: An edited proof sheet with three poems: "Old Age's Lambent Peaks," "A Carol Closing Sixty-Nine," "To Get the Final Lilt of Songs," all published first in 1888. In addition to corrections, Whitman has written a note to the printer at the top of the page.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.note: 20 impressions, (slips like this) ‸on good paper& thentake out the name "Walt Whitman" & 5 impressions more

lg.l:
The touch of flame—the illuminating fire—the loftiest look
at last,

O'er city, passion, sea—o'er prairie, mountain, wood—the
earth itself;
The airy, different‸/,/ hanging hues of all, in falling twilight.,,/
Objects and groups, bearings, faces, reminiscences;
The calmer sight—the golden setting, clear and broad:

So much i' the atmosphere, the points of view, the situa-
tions,& whence we scan,

Bro't out by them alone—so much (perhaps the best) un-
reck'd before;
The lights indeed from them—old age's lambent peaks.
A carol closing sixty-nine—a resume—a repition,
My lines in joy and hope continuing on the same.,/
Of ye‸,/ O God, Life, Nature, Freedom, Poetry;

Of you‸,/ my Land—your rivers, prairies, States—you, mot-
tled Flag I love‸,/

Your aggregate retain'd entire—Of north, south, east and
west, your items all;
Of me myself—the jocund heart yet beating in my breast,

The body wreck'd, old, poor and paralyzed—the strange in-
ertia falliun/g pall-like round me;
The burning fires down in my sluggish blood not yet extinct.,
The undiminish'd faith—the groups of loving friends.

div.head: TO GET THE FINAL LILT OF SONGS.

lg.l: To get the final lilt of songs,

To penetrate the inmost lore of poets—to know the mighty
ones,
Jobs, Homer, Eschylus, Dante, Shakspere, Tennyson, Emerson;

To diagnose the shiftli/ng-delicate tints of love and pride‸and doubt—to
truly understand,
To encompass these, the last keen faculty and entrance-pricce,
Old age‸,/ and what it brings from all its past experiences.
